review_title: Nice Working Place but Poor Management
job_title: IT Service Desk in Kuala Lumpur
pros: Working environment is good and colleagues are very caring and helpful to new joiners. There are a lot of skills you can learn from their online course websites and get certificates from it.
cons: Some managers are passive when they are handling severe issues. For example, internet claims for WFH during MCO takes 1 year to process and haven't announce the receiving date yet.

pros: Free Snacks every other month
cons:
Terrible management and accountability. These guys run the operation by making everyone submit all the work they do every day by typing out a word document. The shift leads are then required to go through it and tell you everything you did wrong. If there is more than a 15-minute gap, you will be asked about it. No matter how hard you try, there is always something wrong and trust me I tried for years too look at this process with a growth mindset. Instead of actually doing work, a lot of time is spent covering your back. 

Management holds monthly meetings where the shift leads are required to give up one of their team members as “low-performing,” whether it’s true or not. In other words, senior management believes it’s I’m possible to have a team where all team members are good workers, and so they make the shift leads call out a member of the team as low-performing each month. They also are required to tell management about a team member that is excelling at work. The shift leads are then expected to provide feedback and corrective actions to the low performer and nothing happens for the over-achiever—not even positive feedback. The meeting is literally just created to paint the narrative that everything wrong is because of a few technicians. The morale has been low for years and confidence in management has been just the same.

Management plays favorites and if you suck up enough you won’t have any issues. If you try to innovate you will get ideas stolen and other team mates and managers WILL try to take credit for it. It’s the most unreal and unprofessional environment I’ve ever worked at. I was heavily advised by a couple of supervisors and senior technicians during my first year at the company to get promoted to another department as soon as possible because this department is terrible, but I just thought those colleagues were childish and didn’t have a growth mindset. It turns out that I just didn’t see all the wrongdoings at the company early on. Despite putting in years of effort, innovation i offered which was inspired by years of operational EXPERIENCE at other companies just couldn’t compete with the ideas upper management got after reading dollar-store management books. Those supervisors and technicians that told me to change roles/get promoted to another department in my first year of employment were right. 

Unfortunately, there is nothing to be gained for an over-achiever who aims to make a career at this company in the Datacenter Technician role. Another big part of the reason for this is nepotism. There are way too many family members and friends from high school in upper management... there needs to be an investigation into this. 

I have brought up many issues to HR at IBM Cloud but their HR is a joke. 

Efficiency is not a word that’s used very often at the company.

This place is a joke.

pros: Maybe I'm lucky to have good management, but the work-life-balance at IBM has been incredible. Additionally, it is a great place to further your education as there are internal incentives in place to do so.
cons: There are layoffs from time to time, and it's hard to gauge what will be effected and when.

pros: Flexibility is amazing. Many good managers out there and only a few bad apples.
cons:
No GDP
No bonuses 
Old school corporate culture 
Not diverse

pros:
- Traveling to different places
- Meeting different kinds of clients and co-workers
- Office space was nice
- Many intelligent co-workers
- If you can survive for two years, it is very easy to go to another firm
cons:
- Managers ask you to lie about your work hours, so you end up working 12-14 a day and don't get paid for it (against the supposed company policy, but that's IBM for you)
- Incredibly sexist
- Public consulting has better work hours, so commercial consulting is the worse off section to work in (see the first bullet)
- You receive several managers above you, and no one really cares much where you are going, just if you are doing your job (you can't switch positions, you can't ask for training for your area of work, you can't receive support in harassment situations)
- Do not work in DC if you are in commercial consulting - no one from that area comes to the office so networking is difficult
- For some reason, the upper level of the office had a nice coffee maker, and the downstairs had terrible coffee which eventually was taken away altogether - pretty symbolic of how the upper level really doesn't care much for lower levels (and it was just bizarre not to have any access to coffee when that is essentially the first item companies have?). Hopefully, they fixed this by now.
- Taking vacations will lower your utilization rate, so even if you have time to take off, don't if you're close to the borderline where you get fired
- There were several phases of layoffs, particularly the newly hired, which was incredibly unlucky for those who didn't get a chance to have any project experience (I believe this got rectified because IBM over hired college students)
- Getting fired was very easy; heard about co-workers who were in the wrong place at the wrong time with little to no heads up
- Getting the right manager was uncommon as the good ones always left IBM quickly, so chances are you are going to get a manager that pushes you around, throws you under the bus, and asks you to work weekends/late nights with no heads up. If you get one of the good ones, they are fantastic. 
- There is definitely an IBM character: focused on work, no time for hobbies (unless it is exercise), comes off cold, enjoys networking, family comes second, enjoys talking about what status they have in each airline/hotel chain. If you fit that stereotype, then this is a great place for you - it just wasn't aligning with my values.

job_title: Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: You get to switch project/products every 3 or 4 years, depending on what is trending. The projects loosely follow Agile methodologies. Saying you know Agile and GIT is a plus. Benefits are good, more options for medical insurances, IBM lags behind on onsite perks like free food, but it is trying to entice new blood to join, so there is a lot of new-hire benefits and events.
cons: When there is layoffs, which comes every other year, it is more important to be in good terms with your management and being in the right product in the right work location. Else the layoffs come regardless of your skills. Below average salary once you've been in the company 5 years. Bad business decisions leads to layoffs. Agile methodologies means there is zero downtime between the product releases.
